step1.sentence: If you plan ahead, you will avoid most of the last-minute stress.

step2.story: She had always planned ahead — further than most people found comfortable. What she had learned was that planning too far ahead had its own costs: plans made in ignorance of future conditions often had to be scrapped, and the effort of making them was wasted. The art was planning far enough to be ready and close enough to reality to be useful.

step3.story: The supply chain disruption had hit their competitors hard. The company had planned ahead eighteen months earlier, identifying single-source dependencies and building buffer inventory for critical components. The decision had been unpopular at the time — it tied up capital that could have been deployed elsewhere, and the risk it was hedging against had seemed unlikely. When the disruption arrived, the company was the only player in their market segment able to fill orders. Planning ahead, the CFO noted in the quarterly letter, was expensive until it was not.

meaning.shortExampleEn: Always plan ahead when organizing a large event.
